According to section 140 of Indian penal code, Whoever, not being a soldier, sailor or airman in the Military, Naval or Air service of the Government of India, wears any garb or carries any token resembling any garb or token used by such a soldier, sailor or airman with the intention that it may be believed that he is such a soldier, sailor or airman, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three months, or with fine which may extend to five hundred rupees, or with both.


IPC 140 in Simple Words
If someone who is not a military member wears a uniform or carries something resembling a military uniform to deceive others into believing they are a soldier, sailor, or airman, they can be punished with up to three months in jail, a fine of up to five hundred rupees, or both.
Offense: Wearing the dress or carrying any token used by a soldier, sailor or airman with intent that it may be believed that he is such a soldier, sailor or airman
Actual Punishment:
The person wearing the uniform without having an active duty as a naval officer, army officer and air force personnel would be liable under this act.

According to section 127 of Indian penal code, Whoever receives any property knowing the same to have been taken in the commission of any of the offences mentioned in sections 125 and 126, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine and to forfeiture of the property so received.


IPC 127 in Simple Words
If someone receives property knowing it was taken during the commission of certain offenses (mentioned in sections 125 and 126), they can be punished with imprisonment of up to seven years, fined, and the property can be forfeited.
Offense: Receiving property taken by war or depredation mentioned in sections 125 And 126
Actual Punishment:
Whoever receives any property knowing that such property has been obtained under an offence referred to in clause (a) of sub-section (1).
The word ‘knowing’ means having knowledge; not merely being aware but actually believing that what one is doing constitutes theft. The fact whether there exists actual belief on part of person receiving the stolen goods will depend upon circumstances as well as facts known at relevant time when he takes possession thereof.

Explanation:- In case where no intention to steal appears from other acts committed alongwith this particular act then mere presence would amount sufficient evidence against him. It should however be kept in mind here that if some other criminal offense is alleged together with the crime of stealing then the prosecution cannot rely entirely upon his own statement alone without adducing independent corroborative material to show beyond reasonable doubt the guilt of defendant.

Example- A man steals a bicycle and hides its key somewhere near the scene of robbery. Later on police arrest another thief who had robbed the cycle before taking away the key and identifies him as guilty robber. Such identification does not make out the case unless the accused admits ownership himself and makes confession admitting all the particulars about the bike including its value etc., even though the said confession itself contains nothing more than suspicion. This rule applies both to oral statements made voluntarily by accused and written statements signed after interrogation by Police Officer

Abetment means helping someone else do something wrong while knowing they will get caught doing so.
